bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, August 31, 1939

div1.p: Moran informs Hench that he has asked Kean to assist him in his yellow fever research. Moran writes that the Camp Lazear site is unrestricted - it is not necessary to request permission to take photographs of the area.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, August 31, 1939
div1.opener:
Havana, Aug. 31, 1939.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
When I received your letter dated April 21st I was
preparing to take a little vacation in the U. S. in company with Mrs.
Moran, the first one in eleven years. I go North every two or three
years on business, never spending over a week in God's Country, one
or two days of which I devote to shopping. Since your letter did not
call for an urgent reply, I postponed writing to you prior to my entry
on leave. When I returned on July 1st, the exchange situation here
had me worrying and it has kept me worrying ever since. The bottom
began to fall out of the Cuban Peso in June and the situation became
panicky in July. August has shown but little improvement. Today, the
last day of the month, the Cuban Peso being worth 85-3/4¢ of an American
Dollar, leaves us in a bad way. We all hope, however, that it will im-
prove before the end of the year. The Cuban Government has several
plans in mind for stabilizing the Peso, none of which have been enforced
or put into practice so far. Up until four years ago, our peso was on
a par with the Dollar. The drop in its value today is a very serious
matter for importers.

Now, with refrence to your proposed visit to Cuba.
You have known right along, of course, that I would be entirely at your
service, when and as you might decide to come here. I do not plan on
leaving Cuba during the coming year. I would suggest, however, that
if you could arrange to come to Havana in February, instead of March, you
would find it more agreeable. While we do not have very hot weather in
March, it is more agreeable in February. So far as I am concerned, it
makes no difference as to the month you may elect. You need not worry
that you will have any difficulty in taking all the pictures you want of
the site of Camp Lazear. A picture of the site would have little meaning
aside from its sentimental value. Pictures of Camp Lazear, as it was
when we guinea pigs were there, are available on application to the Army
Medical Library, that is to say, photostatic copies of the camp. It will
not be necessary to apply for permits of any kind, I am quite sure.

Just yesterday, I wrote a very long letter to General
Kean, informing him that I had hopes of your sponsoring, either in book
form or in the form of an article to be published in one of the accredit-
ed medical journals, the real history of yellow fever, with special refer-
ence to the parts played by Reed and Finlay in what we have come to know
as “The Conquest of Yellow Fever”. I voiced the hope that General Kean
would collaborate with you. While he was Major Reed's intimate friend,
his opinion would be strictly impartial. You could bank on that. The
Cubans, based on the practically unanimous opinion of the Cuban medicos,
claim ALL FOR FINLAY. That stand, of course, is untenable. Ignorance of
Finlay's contribution to the conquest of yellow fever is excusable, to a
certain extent, in the United States. Denial of Reed's share, however,
on the part of the Cubans, is altogether inexcusable. The epidemic of
yellow fever which was raging while his experiments were being carried on
happened to be in Cuba and it was in this country that the experiments
were carried out. There are too many Cuban medicos still living who
know the facts very well. In order to glorify Finlay, they find it con-
Dr. Philip S. Hench.
-- 2 --
Aug. 31, 1939.
venient to forget it. With my letter to you, dated October 30, 1938,
I sent you a copy of a letter General Kean wrote to me, dated April 12,
1938. That letter was read at a session of the Rotary Club here and
its reading and publication in the Havana leading dailies next day only
served to rile Dr. Finlay's self-appointed champion, Dr. Francisco Dominguez
Roldan. The latter, by the way, was present at the Rotary Club session
and when called upon for a few remarks he reiterated his well known claims
for Finlay, classifying as spurious and pertaining to FINLAY ONLY all the
honors accorded to Reed in marble, bronze, books on the subject written by
American authors and the Congressional Record. You will not, if you take
the trouble to re-read General Kean's letter, that he does not take the
stand of the Cubans so much into account as I do. That is due to the fact
that I am here in their midst and continually reading the claims made for
Finlay, to the exclusion of Reed, more virulent with each passing year. So
far as the Cubans are concerned, this matter will not be allowed to die out.

I think you will agree with me that the relative shares
of Reed and Finlay have never been clearly and impartially stated in any
of the books dealing with the subject at issue. Dr. Kelly's “Walter Reed
and Yellow Fever”, the only book I know of which deals exclusively with
the matter, contains many errors. The first edition of that book I have,
having donated the second edition, presented to me by the author, to the
University of Virginia, The Alderman Library having neither edition. The
second edition contains letters and other data supplied by Dr. Carroll and
admitted by the author, dealing principally with the experiments carried
out by Carroll, not as a member of the Army Commission or Board headed by
Major Reed. You will notice from “The Roll of Honor” that some of Dr.
Carroll's cases occurred as late as October, 1901, while the work of the
Reed Yellow Fevr Board wound up in February, 1901.

I am pleased to know that, in general, you find the
article in the SATEVEPOST by J. C. Furnas interesting. At that, it has
quite a few errors, correction of which, I regret, I did not have an
opportunity to make when he finally completed it. I gave him fool-proof
details as to names, dates and places but he evidently got a few of them
mixed in the shuffle. That is to be expected from newspaper reporters
and writers.

I am glad to inform you that my duodenal ulcer has not
given me any trouble now in over eight months. While I was in the U. S.
I could not live up to my regimented diet very well but none the less I
escaped any reminder of its presence with me. I hope to be completely
cured at the end of the year but I expect to watch my diet carefully for
the rest of my days.

Will let you know of General Kean's reaction as soon as
I hear from him. In the meantime, if you have time to write to me, your
letters will be always very welcome. With kindest personal regards, I
remain,
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, John J. Moran.
